answers.answer: I think it depends on what your doctor has done in the past. I know some are c-sect gung ho and others refuse to do it unless there are complications or a hx of previous c-sect.I personally would not elect to have one. Why go through major surgery just so I can pick a convienant time to have the baby.

It really does depend on your dr.  I have a few friends that did it that way because they have other children and because they planned a tummy tuck at the same time.It's up to your dr but for me, I think the healing time for a vaginal birth is a lot easier ESPECIALLY if you have other kids you need ot watch and pick up etc.Also, it's not nice to mess with Mother Nature.I am having a planned inducement at 37 weeks but I've been high risk from day one and they didn't think I would make it to 37 weeks.  I plan on trying to go it naturally and by naturally I mean vaginally not withhout drugs.  I'm no martyr.  Ha Ha.

I had a C-section and PERSONALLY I would have rather had a natural birth.  You heal so much faster after a vaginal birth than a C-section.  I was in sooo much pain (I may be a wuss but I thought it was painful afterwards)!!  But this time I have to schedule a C-section due to a narrow pelvis that will prevent me from have a vaginal birth (per the dr. VBAC is out of the question)  I really wanted to try natural too but what can you do.  Right?As for the answer to your question I dont know if this is offered or not.  I didnt think they did C-sections uless there was a problem or you needed to have one.  Sometimes they know before hand whether you will be able to have natural or not.GOOD LUCK!!

personally, i would say go with the vaginal delivery if possible.  they can always schedule the induction around a convenient time and there is a lot let hospital stay afterwards.  i delivered my first vaginally, after going into labor naturally.  i was in the hospital for 2 1/2 days and was up and around soon after.  with my second i had gestational diabetes and had ripped pretty bad with the first.  since he was measuring quite larger than my first and babies born to mothers with gd tend to have larger shoulders and chests we decided not to take the risk of him getting stuck.  so we had a scheduled csection.it was nice in that we picked the bday and my recovery wasn't that bad, i attribute it to an absolutely wonderful doctor.  i am now expecting number 3 and would like to go naturally again, however it is not an option as it's been less than two years between the two and we don't want to risk any abruptions.  i am glad that i don't have to worry about going into labor, but then again, i could pick the bday and she could decide to come a week earlier.either way it takes a lot of thought not only into the process but the after effects.  i have to say the worst pain i have ever felt was the 2wks of constipation after the csection from the morphine.  one thing they never really told me about.good luck to you and the choice you make.

Will doctors schedule inductions (not a c-sect) if a woman requests?  I know a lot of pregnant women right now are due early Jan 2007 but want baby in Dec 2006 due to tax write off and dedct/co-ins already met.

Gotcha, that is also what I thought too.   Figure my pumpkin will come when he/she is damn well ready. :) I also am due in the winter so I will not have to deal with the heat like some of these poor gals right now.

you are so lucky.  my first, dd, was born in july and it was sooooo hot.  my second, ds, was born in jan. and let me tell you it was heaven.  i had hot flashes after the delivery due to the hormones, and all i had to do was walk outside in the snow for a minute and whew, felt so much better.  plus, i had time to get rid of all the baby wt. for the following summer.  :)

I agree with the waiting now, I wasn't sure, I'm so anxious to meet her. I'm only 22weeks now so I still have forever to go, this is my 2nd pregnancy, my DS was delivered vaginally. Sounds like that's the best way again. Thank you ladies.

My opinion is to just do what you feel is right. I had my daughter vaginally, and although I have never had a c-section, NO ONE can tell me the healing is easier naturally as opposed to c-section. So pain wise, I believe its a toss up. But myself, I had some sort of satisfaction, knowing my body did its job and pushed the kid out! lol Nothing against c-sections, a lot of them are absolutely necessary (sp?)

i dont know the pain from healing from a natural del. i suppose if tearing or an episiotomy(sp) was the case it might hurt like hell. i had a c section due to my son being face up heartbeat dropping (i had multiple contractions without a break!) and i pushed for a few hours before. the recovery wasnt that bad really. you know how you forget the pain. for the first week or so it was hard to get up and hard to do certain things. i really would have liked having a vaginal birth. to experience pushing him out. sounds crazy im sure lo. i do know a couple whom the hubby is an attorney and she is a cpa big money! well the hubby didnt want to be woken up in the middle of the night with this so they scheduled induction. crazy. the baby is ready she they are ready. do what you feel best and nobody can tell you different! good luck to you and i hope all goes well

i'm sure any good dr. would only schedule an induction if it is appropriate for the baby's gestation.  it's scary to think that they may do it for the convenience of the parent's taxes.  from a lot of questions i've asked my dr. she has said that they only schedule induction after at least 38wks gestation for mothers who have had children, and sometimes only after the due date for first time mothers.  this is to ensure the baby's lungs and organs are developed enough.  i know with my first i was scheduled for an induction, no kidding, four weeks after her due date.  i had a really bad dr. then.  luckily she came on her own the day before the scheduled induction.  my dr. now, whom i've had for almost 6 yrs, promised me i would never go after my due date.  but again, that is something needing to be talked about between you and your dr.my sis was induced at 37 wks with my niece d/t preeclampsia, but taht was after extensive testing and u/s to ensure the baby was ready, and was to save my sis.it feels like forever, trust me again this is number 3, but when you have that healthy little one in your arms and you know that it was all your hard work to make them so perfect it is so worth the wait.

Once again, nothing against c-sections when needed, they save plenty of babies/mothers lives. But the pain thing, a c-section recovery cannot hurt more than a vaginal recovery. At least in my case. I didn't have any major complications, but I had a very intense labor, and my daughter was a healthy 8lbs, 10oz, 20 inches long, with her being my first baby and being large,I had a second degree tear that required 25+ stitches. Plus, as she was coming down the birth canal, she left lesions on my inner walls. So it was a long painful recovery.

I ended up having a c-section after 17 hours of labor, and let me tell you, that was the worst pain I have ever felt!  The healing was horrible.  I sure hope I can have a vaginal delivery this time!  I know it must hurt to some degree with a vaginal birth, but if you have never had a c-section you don't know what it's like.  I felt like my insides were going to come out, I cried every time I had to get up, the first week was total HELL!  Everyone I know that had vaginal deliveries have been out and about walking around within days of delivery... not that way with the c-section.  I would say to wait for it to come naturally if you can.

I agree it depends on the Dr.  Mine would not schedule a C-section just for convience, and would not induce early unless it was medically necessary, made me wait a good week and a half overdue.  I had a vaginal birth, but I should have had a C-section, my son was so large, but he hid so well that we didn't know till he was crowning.  I had a really rough recovery and after a year I still had a lot of pain from nerve damage.  It got better, not to freak anyone out, but sometimes the C-section is better.  I hope to have a vaginal birth again this time though, and hopefully this little one will be smaller.  I will also be induced a little early this time.  Personaly, the thought of a C-section scares me, but I'm a wuss too.

Yeah, I agree!  It sounds like everyone has had their own personal experiences good and bad with c-sections/vaginal deliveries.I think just like every woman is different in their preferences, every doctor is different in their views on inductions and scheduled c-sections.  I had a scheduled induction at 39.4 weeks for no major medical reason.  My cousin was super jealous b/c her doctor refused.  I had a vaginal with 3rd degree tearing, 30+ stiches and a painful recovery, while my best friend had a practically pain free c-section.  It's a toss up!  :)Amy
i guess the results are in. both ways to deliver suck haha.

I just want to jump into say that my surgery was cake and it was an emergency c-section after 2 days of labor so I am sure a planned one would be a lot easier.  My recovery time was fine and my only complaint was the amount of fluid they shoved in me during labor and then the surgery. I was totally swollen.  My stitches dissolved on their own and was just fine.  I discharge myself after less than 2 days.  I was out shopping that weekend.  I had no issues and only took 800mg of Motrin for pain.  I really want to do a VBAC but a part of me has seen some nasty vaginal births and severe tears. My girlfriend was on a donut for 2-3wks after and has urinary incontinence now - not fun.  So it is a difficult decision but I also think it is a personal decision for everyone. Do what you feel is best.

Its all up to you. I had a c section for my first child and didnt find it a problem it was sore but not that bad I was walking the following day I didnt have labour which was a bonus I was induced but it failed. Im 24 weeks pregnant now and are not sure wether I need another c section or not it wouldnt worry me I wouldnt mind trying a natural birth to see what its like but I've have some friends that have had traumatic births that it scares me a bit one of my friends had her baby delivered by forceps and she said her healing time was 7 weeks with c section for me it was 6 weeks but I guess everyone heals in different ways good luck.

question: I saw on a documentary; a woman that scheduled her delivery, she had no complications but just wanted the birth to be planned. Does anyone know if that is possible, or can only rich people do that?If so, what's your opinion on a scheduled birth rather than waiting for baby to make the entry naturally?(this question is geared towards no complications, I know if it comes down to it, everyone is subject to C-Section)
title: Schedule a C-Section?
